intro: Juncus fuscatus, commonly known as the brown rush, is a perennial plant native to wetland and marsh environments across North America. It features tall, cylindrical stems covered in a dense layer of fine, grass-like leaves. The plant produces small, inconspicuous flowers in clusters near the base of the stems, typically in late spring to early summer. Its rhizomatous growth habit allows it to spread and form dense colonies, which help stabilize soil in wetland habitats. Juncus fuscatus is often used in ecological restoration projects due to its ability to filter water and provide habitat for various wildlife species.
